H0.text: Net force is the result when one subtracts the frictional force from the applied force in physics.

H1.text: Rolled force is the result obtained when, in physics, the frictional force is subtracted from the applied force.

H2.text: Quarter force is the result when one subtracts the frictional force from the applied force in physics.

H3.text: Kinetic force is the result when one subtracts the frictional force from the applied force in physics.

A4.text: In mechanics, the net force is the sum of all the forces acting on an object.

A5.text: The resultant force is the single force and associated torque obtained by combining a system of forces and torques acting on a rigid body via vector addition.

A6.text: The sum of these forces and torques yields the resultant force-torque.

A7.text: The net force upon the body is determined by the manner in which the potential energy decreases.

A8.text: The static friction force must be overcome by an applied force before an object can move.

A9.text: the applied force is opposed by static friction, generated between the object and the table surface.

A10.text: The kinetic friction force is typically independent of both the forces applied and the movement of the object.

A11.text: These laws describe the relationship between the forces acting on a body and the motion of that body.

A12.text: Force (F→ = m a→) is equal to the change in momentum per change in time (Δm v→ Δt).
